repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise
            Competitiveness Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Micro, Small and
            Medium Enterprise Competitiveness Project for Kenya was
            moderately satisfactory with a substantial risk to
            development outcome.  Both the Bank and Borrower's
            performances were moderately satisfactory. Although the
            Project suffered serious delays under several subcomponents
            in the first two to three years, implementation started to
            accelerate in 2007 and went into full swing after the 2009
            restructuring. Of the eight intermediate results, five were
            met or exceeded, two were largely met and one was partially
            met. Several lessons are learnt from this experimental joint
            Bank/IFC Operation: innovations can succeed under Bank
            financed projects, if the environment for innovations is
            favorable, and the implementing entities know the local
            market well and are highly motivated; details are important
            in project design and supervision; better approach is needed
            for joint IDA-IFC operations; monitoring and evaluation
            (M&E) design should factor in the cost and capacity
            requirement; and standard economic analysis methodology may
            not be universally applicable pending the nature of the main
            interventions of a project.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise
            Competitiveness Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprise
            (MSMEs) Competitiveness Project aims to increase
            productivity, and employment in participating MSMEs, by
            strengthening financial, and non-financial markets to meet
            the their demand, strengthening institutional support for
            employable skills, and business management, and, reducing
            critical investment climate constraints on MSMEs. The
            Project has largely achieved the project development
            objective (PDO) outcomes, and overall project implementation
            is satisfactory with most of the intermediate results at the
            component level fully achieved. The final rating for
            development objective (DO) is satisfactory and that for
            implantation progress (IP) also satisfactory. The
            disbursement rate is 72 percent as of June 27, 2012. The
            restructuring is to reallocate International Development
            Association (IDA) credit between different disbursement
            categories to reflect a parallel cancellation of US$6.6
            million. While the majority of planned activities have been
            implemented with good results, there appears to be
            overestimates of costs for several main activities, leading
            to a balance of US$6.6 million of the IDA credit unutilized.
            At the same time, the Government of Kenya has clearly
            indicated where the funds can be better used within the
            Bank's country portfolio.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise
            Competitiveness Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprise
            (MSMEs) Competitiveness Project aims to increase
            productivity, and employment in participating MSMEs, by
            strengthening financial, and non-financial markets to meet
            the their demand, strengthening institutional support for
            employable skills, and business management, and, reducing
            critical investment climate constraints on MSMEs. Through
            its components, the project will: 1) deepen and expand the
            reach of financial services, and products available to
            MSMEs, including new risk capital instruments. This will be
            achieved through performance based matching grants, to
            assist a range of financial institutions build capacity to
            provide financial services to different segments of MSME
            sector; 2) strengthen enterprise skills and market linkages,
            by addressing market failures that limit the ability of
            MSMEs in obtaining the necessary skills and business
            services to exploit opportunities and overcome bottlenecks.
            It integrates a set of complementary, and mutually
            reinforcing activities to support enterprise needs,
            including a value-chain based subsector matching grant fund,
            tools for business schools to better train managers,
            business plan competition to catalyze innovation, and
            entrepreneurship, and restructuring of the national levy
            scheme, to ensure sustainability of firm-level training; 3)
            reduce compliance costs in business regulations regarding
            the formal sector, and create incentives for informal MSMEs
            to graduate to higher levels of formality, and thus
            facilitate their access to resources for growth. It will
            assist in implementing the simplified taxation regime for
            micro, and small businesses, and in reducing the cost of
            starting-up businesses, through a one-stop shop approach.
